version.name: Manta featuring MAP
version.description: Rock: Manta is a six-and-a-half-foot tall singer-songwriter and her backing band is called MAP. They perform easy-listening rock, which could be described as Dave Matthews-meets-John Lennon-meets-Sheryl Crow. The house band Toya also performs throughout the week

version.name: Jim Morrison night
version.description: Get your mojo risin’ and pay tribute to the lizard king at a night dedicated to the music of Morrison and The Doors, at the bar named after the man himself

version.name: Shah Shabad
version.description: A solo exhibition by Geeta Vadhera depicting Shah Shabad – the words of Bulleh Shah. Visual Arts Gallery

version.name: Jena Kriti
version.description: A solo exhibition of paintings by Kashinath Jena depicting the various forms of Radha Krishna and Gautam Buddha. Open Palm Court Gallery

version.name: Delhi Nama
version.description: An exhibition about the history of Delhi by Delhi Urban Arts Commission from the Palaeolithic Age to Master Plan 2021 through photographs, drawings, paintings, maps and audio-visuals. Delhi ‘O’ Delhi Foyer

version.name: India – Abode Of The Gods
version.description: An exhibition by Tarun Chhabra

version.name: Permanent collection
version.description: The gallery houses works by modern Indian painters, including Krishen Khanna, Manu Parekh, T Vaikuntam, GR Iranna, Ram Bali Chauhan, Phaneendra Nath Chaturvedi, Sudhanshu Sutar and Neeraj Goswami

version.name: Various
version.description: Hindustani classical: A music and dance festival, in the memory of Pandit Kundanlal Gangani has been organised by Harish Gangani

version.name: Various
version.description: Hindustani classical: A music and dance festival, in the memory of Pandit Kundanlal Gangani has been organised by Harish Gangani

version.name: In the Further Soil
version.description: Musical: A musical theatre production inspired by a text by Rabindranath Tagore. Set in India and the UK, it explores the changing identities of today’s youth through music, dance and spoken word. Set to the sounds of jazz and afro-beat, mixed with Bengali baul music. Directed by Harmage Singh Kalirai and written by Satinder Kaur Chohan and a cast featuring Shelley King, Soweto Kinch, Anusha Subramanyam, Ratul Shankar Ghosh, Dibyendu Mukherji and Sanjukta Ray. Call venue for passes

event.name: Ronkini Gupta + Subrata De + Anuradha Pal

version.name: Ronkini Gupta + Subrata De + Anuradha Pal
version.description: A vocal recital by Ronkini Gupta from Kolkata, winner of Zee Sa Re Ga Ma 2004, a sitar recital by Subrata De and a performance by tabla maestro Anuradha Pal from Mumbai

version.name: Saptarshi Chakraborty
version.description: A vocal recital by Saptarshi Chakraborty from Kolkata. He will be accompanied by Damodar Lal (harmonium), Nishith Kumar and Tansen Shrivastava (tabla).

version.name: Media nights
version.description: TCs Adchini’s brought back media nights. Flash your press card or business card and get a flat 50 per cent off.

version.name: Khataak!
version.description: A mobile phone photo exhibition that called for submissions from all across the world will be exhibited in the lanes of Hauz Khas village. This is an attempt to re-place art in public, giving them the freedom to view it or disregard it. For location details, contact the studio

version.name: Faridkot
version.description: Rock: Rock with a Hindi flavour by Akshay Raheja (keys), Rajarshi Sanyal (guitar), Gavin Pacheco (bass), Reuben Narain (drums) and Inderpreet Singh (vocals).

version.name: The Circus
version.description: The Circus’ grounds are in upscale Anand Niketan, a really quiet neighbourhood, the sort of place where the noisiest residents are presumably highly pedigreed dogs. Arsh Sharma’s home, where the band rehearses, is equally deceptive. You’d never guess that some of the most furious and unconventional music being made in the city (insane compositions about samurais who can’t swim, songs dripping with disdain for no-hope cover bands) is being made in here

version.name: Time Out Be-the-Bartender Night
version.description: Show off your barkeep skills and take a turn as guest bartender at the scarlet simian. Call ahead to hook it up

version.name: CWG special
version.description: The Island Bar is feeling that Games spirit, and over this period will be decorated like a stadium, will serve drinks around the clock, telecast all the sporting events on huge screens and host “exclusive game attractions”. Choose cocktails from their specially themed CWG drinks

version.name: Cuenta Cuentos
version.description: Latin jazz: Cuenta Cuentos (which means “storyteller” in Spanish) mixes various genres, with somewhat of an acoustic approach. The band started off Spanish music and jazz at the Aman in Delhi last year. Currently, the band comprises Parvati M Krishnan (vocal), Mhaseve Tetseo (guitar), Clarence Gonsalves (bass) and Nikhil Mawkin (drums)

version.name: Weaving Legacy
version.description: An exhibition to mark the tenth anniversary of the gallery includes works by stalwarts such as MF Hussain, Anjolie Ela Menon and Rini Dhumal

event.name: The Joy of a New Harvest

version.name: The Joy of a New Harvest
version.description: A solo show by Siddharta Shingade. Shingade uses reds, yellows and parrot greens to paint scenes from his native land Marathwada. The works, which fuse abstraction with figures, is part of a fundraiser that will support the treatment of critically-ill children

version.name: Reverie
version.description: A solo exhibition by Pankaj Mistry

event.name: The Map is Not the Territory

version.name: The Map is Not the Territory
version.description: A solo show by Sujith SN who paints a sad picture of chaotic cities going through a construction overdrive. Sound familiar?

version.name: Permanent collection
version.description: This collection includes MF Husain, FN Souza, SH Raza and others

version.name: Permanent collection
version.description: Rahul & Art has an excellent permanent collection, including works by MF Husain, Tyeb Mehta, Ram Kumar, SH Raza, Ganesh Pyne, Krishen Khanna and a heritage collection of Bengal masters such as Rabindranath Tagore, Mukul Dey, Gopal Ghosh, Gaganendranath Tagore’s Darjeeling series and a rare Shakuntala canvas by AH Muller

version.name: Fortitude From Fragments
version.description: A solo show by Rumanna Hussain

version.name: Ladies’ night
version.description: DJ Rahul plays and women get 50 per cent off on all drinks

version.name: Pandit Debu Chaudhuri + Sudha Raghunathan
version.description: Chaudhuri is a leading sitarist, while Raghunathan is a renowned vocalist in the Carnatic tradition

version.name: Pandit Ram Narayan + Gundecha Brothers
version.description: Narayan is responsible for elevating the sarangi as a solo instrument and freeing it from its status as an accompanying instrument. Umakant and Ramakant are from Bhopal and are arguably the finest exponents of dhrupad singing today

version.name: Bhajan Sopori + Pandit Chhannulal Mishra
version.description: Along with Shiv Kumar Sharma, Sopori is the most well-known santoor player today. He is credited with modifying the instrument to increase its range. Mishra is a classical singer from Varanasi and a noted exponent of the Kirana gharana. He is known for his renditions of khayal and the purab ang thumri

version.name: Ustad Shujaat Khan + Wadali Brothers
version.description: The son of the legendary Ustad Vilayat Khan, sitarist Shujaat Khan belongs to the famous Etawah gharana, which is also known as the Imdadkhani gharana, named after his ancestor Imdad Khan. The Wadali brothers are famous Sufi singers from Amritsar in Punjab

version.name: Rashid Mustafa Thirakawa + Aruna Sairam
version.description: Thirakawa belongs to a family that has produced some of the finest tabla players in the country, including his father Mohammad Jan Khan and his uncle Ahmed Jan. Aruna Sairam is one of the foremost Carnatic vocalists today

event.name: Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia + Pandit Ajoy Chakraborty

version.name: Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia + Pandit Ajoy Chakraborty
version.description: Globally, Chaurasia is now synonymous with the sound of the bamboo flute in Hindustani classical music. Charaborty is one of the finest Hindustani classical vocalists today and belongs to the Patiala gharana

event.name: Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt + OS Arun

version.name: Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt + OS Arun
version.description: One of the best-known Indian musicians in the West after he won a Grammy Award with Ry Cooder, Bhatt is the inventor of the Mohan veena which combines elements of the guitar, sitar and the sarod. OS Arun is a rising young Carnatic vocalist.

version.name: An Eye For an Eye
version.description: An exhibition by Indian photographer Raghu Rai and Mexican photographer Graciela Iturbide to commemorate the bicentennary of the independence of Mexico, the centennary of the Mexican Revolution and 60 years of diplomatic relations between India and Mexico

version.name: Neuronal Landscapes
version.description: An exhibition of scientific images of the nervous system by Spanish neuroscientists and others. The variety of forms, the light effects of individual product markings and bright colours remind one of abstract paintings

version.name: Lecture
version.description: A lecture titled “Kunstverein Today” on the institutional model between local cultural affinity and a global context of art

version.name: In the Waves and Underneath
version.description: An exhibition by Pooja Iranna consisting of drawings, canvases, sculptures (using staple pins) and a video projection

version.name: Dual Liquid
version.description: An exhibition of recent prints and sculptures by Sumedh Rajendran that deal with fear and anxieties in domestic life

version.name: Media nights
version.description: Unlimited drinks and snacks

version.name: Twinspotting
version.description: An exhibition of photos of Patel twins from London and Gujarat by photographer Ketaki Sheth

version.name: Qilla Records
version.description: Gaurav (Qilla Records / BLOT) and Kohra (Qilla Records/Zenon) play their distinctive blend of minimal techno and tech-house. SQL (Germany) will join the Qilla boys for a monster tech set

version.name: In the Further Soil
version.description: Musical: A musical theatre production inspired by a text by Rabindranath Tagore. Set in India and the UK, it explores the changing identities of today’s youth through music, dance and spoken word. Set to the sounds of jazz and afro-beat, mixed with Bengali baul music. Directed by Harmage Singh Kalirai and written by Satinder Kaur Chohan and a cast featuring Shelley King, Soweto Kinch, Anusha Subramanyam, Ratul Shankar Ghosh, Dibyendu Mukherji and Sanjukta Ray. Call venue for passes

version.name: Word Perfect
version.description: Tips on being a better communicator. Ages 10-12. For Library members only

version.name: The Number Game
version.description: This workshop by Manisha Verma helps kids develop the ability to understand and tackle the number series. Ages 8-10. For Library members only.

version.name: Understanding Media
version.description: At this workshop by Nutan Chopra, participants will be exposed to the media world with a special focus on newspapers. Ages 12 +.For Library members only.

version.name: The World of Innovations
version.description: Children learn the concepts behind smart innovations at this workshop. Ages 10-14. For Library members only

version.name: Weave a Pattern
version.description: Simi Srivastava conducts a workshop on creating textures by developing patterns using a variety of materials. Ages 7-10. For Library members only.

version.name: The Wild World
version.description: Bhavna Saxena helps kids unravel the mysteries around animals to help them connect better with the natural world. Ages 6-8. For Library members only.

version.name: A Walk in the Future
version.description: The aim of Bhavna Saxena’s workshop is to create an atmosphere of inquisitiveness and logical thinking. Ages 8-11. For Library members only

version.name: Enrich your Vocabulary
version.description: Monisha Gupta conducts this workshop where kids learn to speak confidently using well-chosen vocabulary. Ages 7-9. For Library members only.

version.name: Super Shapes
version.description: Kids explore the fascinating world of shapes to create graphics at this session conducted by Monisha Gupta. Ages 3.5-5. For Library members only.

version.name: Table Laying, the Japanese Way
version.description: Sandhya Bansal shows kids how to lay the table, fold napkins and make colourful coasters, Japanese-style. Ages 8-12. For Library members only.

version.name: Art and creative enquiry workshop
version.description: Katherine Rose and Eliza Hilton of Flow Associates, a UK company, conduct a workshop titled “Creatively Design your City”, to show kids fun, fast-paced and interactive techniques for collaborating creatively and presenting ideas. It will culminate in a collaborative design of a future city. Ages 11+.For Library members only.

version.name: Butterflies, Birds + Spray Cans
version.description: A solo exhibition by UK artist Xenz, who uses spray cans to paint graffiti filled with butterflies and flowers

version.name: Dhoul Dhool Dhappa
version.description: A solo show by Kaushlesh. Triveni Gallery

version.name: News-making workshop
version.description: Select CityWalk and Mark 5 Films organize a news-making workshop which gives kids a chance to interact with professionals in this field. Ages 6-16. For details, call Harpreet Suri (99991-19414).

version.name: Creating Commonwealth
version.description: An exhibition by national and international artists on the theme of colonial rule

version.name: 10x10
version.description: A exhibition including works by Satish Gujral, Manu Parekh and Arpana Caur.

version.name: Bal Sangam
version.description: Performances by kids of traditional art forms from different parts of the country. Presented by Sanskar Rang Toli, or the Theatre in Education Company

version.name: Jashn-e-Bachpan
version.description: The Theatre in Education Company presents a fortnight of 26 plays for children, performed by adults as well as children from around the world. Details not finalised when we went to print. Also see “Swine Flew” in Theatre.

version.name: Robotics camp
version.description: A robotics day camp where participants learn mechanical design, construction, programming and teamwork skills. Ages 7-11. For details, contact (98103-10278, 96543-48322).

version.name: Solo show
version.description: An exhibition by Pakistani artist Amna Ilyas. She uses glass and acrylic for her work and most of her works give an illusion of transparency. Her artistic statement is, “I injured, I destroyed, I smeared and I covered transparency

version.name: Delhi Jazz Club
version.description: Jazz: Drummer Nikhil Vasudevan hosts this show with guest artists

version.name: Lazy River
version.description: Rock: This jam band with influences ranging from blues and blues rock to funk comprises Farid Singh (drums), Meg D’souza (vocals), Jeff Laloo (bass) and Chaitanya Bhalla (guitar)

version.name: The Gas Meters
version.description: Fusion: A progressive instrumental collective playing psychedelic jazz stoner rock. The band’s influences include Miles Davis, Queens of the Stone Age, Pearl Jam, Sonic Youth and Pink Floyd

version.name: The Gas Meters
version.description: Fusion: A progressive instrumental collective playing psychedelic jazz stoner rock. The band’s influences include Miles Davis, Queens of the Stone Age, Pearl Jam, Sonic Youth and Pink Floyd

version.name: Lazy River + DJ Pok-E
version.description: The four-piece indie-rock/funk blues outfit play a psychedelic jam-band oriented set at this Hauz Khas haunt, and Pok-E follows up with a minimal tech and techno set.
